noun.description: Death, destruction, or some other terrible fate.
examples: the aircraft was sent crashing to its doom in the water

verb.description: Condemn to certain destruction or death.
examples: fuel was spilling out of the damaged wing and the aircraft was doomed

phrases: the national feeling of doom and gloom
This is not only good news but encouraging revelations, especially made at the beginning of the year when projections are usually about gloom and doom.
Look, it wasn't all gloom and doom, but like I said - it was getting old.
It's a miraculous way to yank yourself out of gloom and doom.
So the tabloid-style gloom and doom may simply be disinformation.
origin: Old English dōm statute, judgement, of Germanic origin, from a base meaning to put in place; related to do.
